content: The Act titled "Natural Resource Management on Military Lands Act of 1994" amends the Sikes Act to promote wildlife conservation on military reservations. Integrated natural resource management plans are required for military installations. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. The Secretary shall prepare and implement these plans, except when deemed inappropriate. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, except when installation is not appropriate. Amendments include changing references from "cooperative plan" to "integrated natural resource management plan" throughout Title I. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, replacing references to "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" throughout Title I. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, including wetland protection and restoration, consideration of conservation needs for all biological communities, and specific natural resource management goals, objectives, and time-frames. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, addressing fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation. The plans must ensure no net loss in the capability of installation lands to support the military mission. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, ensuring no net loss in the capability of installation lands to support the military mission. The plans also provide for sustained public use of natural resources, public access to the installation, and professional enforcement of natural resource laws and regulations. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations, ensuring no net loss in land capability for the military mission. Plans also include sustained public use of resources, public access, and professional enforcement of laws. Public comment is required for each plan. SEC. 4. REVIEW OF MILITARY INSTALLATIONS FOR INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS. The Secretary of each military department must review all US military installations under their jurisdiction to determine which ones require an integrated natural resource management plan. A report on these determinations must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense within 9 months. The Secretary of Defense must then submit a report to Congress within 12 months. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 12 months after the enactment of this Act, listing military installations where an integrated natural resource management plan is not deemed appropriate, along with explanations for each. Additionally, within 2 years of the report submission, plans must be developed for installations where such determination has not been made. The Secretary of Defense must prepare and implement an integrated natural resource management plan for military installations where such a plan is deemed appropriate, in agreement with the Secretary of the Interior and State agencies. If a cooperative plan is already in place, negotiations must be completed to ensure it complies with the requirements. The Secretary of Defense must allow public comments on proposed integrated natural resource management plans and changes to cooperative plans. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REVIEWS AND REPORTS. Section 101 (16 U.S.C. 670a) is amended to include subsection (g) requiring the Secretary of Defense to review and report on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans annually by March 1. The report must include the number of plans in effect, expenditure on conservation efforts, and other relevant details. The Secretary of Defense must annually review and report on integrated natural resource management plans, including the number of plans, conservation expenditure, and compliance assessment with specific requirements to prevent land loss for military missions. The Secretary of the Interior must submit an annual report on conservation expenditures for integrated natural resource management plans to the Committees on Merchant Marine and Fisheries and Armed Services of the House of Representatives, and the Committees on Armed Services and Environment and Public Works of the Senate. SEC. 6 amends Title I to allow the Secretary of Defense to enforce Federal laws related to natural resource conservation on military installations. SEC. 7 adds a new section for natural resource management services. Title I (16 U.S.C. 670a et seq.) is amended to include a new section 107 for natural resource management services. This requires each military department to have trained personnel for natural resource management and law enforcement to comply with the Act. Additionally, section 108 provides definitions for clarity. The term 'military department' refers to the Army, Navy, and Air Force. 'Military installation' includes US-owned land managed by the Secretary of Defense or a military department. 'State fish and wildlife agency' is a state government agency managing fish and wildlife resources. The term 'wildlife agency' refers to a State government agency responsible for managing fish and wildlife resources. The term 'United States' includes States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and territories. SEC. 9. SHORT TITLE. Title I (16 U.S.C. 670a et seq.) is further amended by inserting after section 108 the following: "SEC. 109. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the 'Sikes Act'." SEC. 10. COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. Cost Sharing.--Section 103a(b) is amended by replacing "matching basis" with "cost-sharing basis". Accounting.--Section 103a(c) is amended to exclude section 1535 of that title. SEC. 11. REPEAL. Section 2 of the Act of October 27, 1986 is repealed. SEC. 12. CLERICAL AMENDMENTS. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections, including changing references in sections 101, 102, and 103. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends sections related to programs on military installations and public lands by updating the years for authorizations of appropriations to 1994, 1995, 1996, and 1997.
